# edar

<!-- badges: start -->
[![R-CMD-check](https://github.com/soutomas/edar/actions/workflows/R-CMD-check.yaml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/soutomas/edar/actions/workflows/R-CMD-check.yaml)
[![Codecov test coverage](https://codecov.io/gh/soutomas/edar/graph/badge.svg)](https://app.codecov.io/gh/soutomas/edar)
<!-- badges: end -->

The goal of edar is to provide some convenient functions for common tasks in exploratory data analysis.

## Citation

Sou T (2025). _edar: Convenient Functions for Exploratory Data Analysis_. R package version 0.0.1, <https://github.com/soutomas/edar>.

```{r}
citation("edar")
```

## Installation

You can install the development version of edar from [GitHub](https://github.com/) with:

``` r
# install.packages("pak")
pak::pak("soutomas/edar")
```

## Example

Commonly, we want to add a label indicating the source file in the output. 

```{r example}
library(edar)
lab1 = label_src(1)
lab1
```
The source label can be directly added to a ggplot object. 

```{r fig.width=4, fig.height=3}
library(ggplot2)
p = ggplot(mtcars, aes(mpg, wt)) +
  geom_point() 
p |> ggsrc()
```

Summary of continuous and categorical variables. 

```{r}
library(dplyr)

# Data 
dat = mtcars |> mutate(vs=factor(vs), am=factor(am))

# Summary for continuous variables in a data frame. 
dat |> summ_by()

# Summary of selected variable after grouping. 
dat |> summ_by("mpg",vs)
dat |> summ_by("mpg",vs,am)

# Summary for categorical variables in a data frame. 
dat |> summ_cat()

# Summary for selected categorical variable. 
dat |> summ_cat("vs")
```

Results can be directly viewed in a flextable object easily. 

```{r}
# Show data frame in a flextable object. 
dat |> summ_by("mpg",vs) |> ft()

# Source label can be easily added. 
dat |> summ_cat("am") |> ft(src=1)
```
